<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_alloc_memory_:
```c
void *
MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                              size_t size)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /* a short alias */
  struct MemoryPool *const pool = c->pool;     /* a short alias */
  size_t need_to_be_freed = 0; /**< The required amount of additional free memory */
  void *res;

  res = MHD_pool_try_alloc (pool,
                            size,
                            &need_to_be_freed);
  if (NULL != res)
    return res;

  if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                     c->write_buffer,
                                     c->write_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset >=
        need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->write_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->write_buffer,
                                 c->write_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset <= new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_send_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->write_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->write_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                          c->read_buffer,
                                          c->read_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->read_buffer_size - c->read_buffer_offset >= need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->read_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->read_buffer,
                                 c->read_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->read_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->read_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else
    return NULL;
  res = MHD_pool_allocate (pool, size, true);
  mhd_assert (NULL != res); /* It has been checked that pool has enough space */
  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>

Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.

scenario: No violation: the fragment performs a size_t arithmetic comparison and does not call any functions from <string.h>. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 concerns use of the string.h functions (memcpy, strcpy, etc.), so it is not applicable here. (Note: as an unrelated remark, if c->write_buffer_append_offset > c->write_buffer_size this subtraction would underflow and could lead to later out-of-bounds accesses — that would be a separate correctness/safety issue but not a direct violation of Rule 21.17.)
